JOHN LEGG . I am in the employ of the Regent's Canal Company. On Sunday morning, 18th May, I was on duty there, near Pickering's Wharf, about two or three hundred yards from it—it is in Limehouse, between the West India Docks and London—I saw men at work at Pickering's Wharf carrying bags—I did not count the men—I saw a barge there—I cannot say, on my oath, what the name was; I could not see any name—I could not see the stern of the barge—she was a cabin barge—the name was in front—to the best of my belief it was the Old Soul, but I never saw the name—all the name I could see was, "OU L," written in front of the barge, in front of the cabin—I know what the stern-sheets are—I saw no name written on the stern-sheets—the men were carrying bags into Mr. Pickering's place, out of the barge on which I saw the "OUL."

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How near were you when you saw the "OU L" on the front of the cabin? A. Between two and three hundred yards from it—it was on the stern of the barge, the end; it was not where the stern-sheets are—I cannot say whether the cabin is ahead or astern of the barge—I was on the Regent's Pier Company's pier-head—there was a pier between me and the barge—it was not higher than I was—our pier-head is level with the top, and the barge was down below; the water was six or eight feet.
Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Is it a usual thing for barges to be emptied on a Sunday? A. No.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. It is not usual? A. No; I have not noticed it—I have been there seven or eight Sundays, and have never seen a barge un
loaded—I was backwards and forwards, on duty, from eight o'clock in the morning till eight in the evening, and this was going on for a considerable part of that time—when I saw the "OU L," I was on the pier—I was higher than the barge, and could see into it, and saw those letters.

COURT. Q. When you saw the letters "OU L," how far were you from the barge? A. Two hundred yards—I saw the "O U L" in front of the cabin—she was lying with her head towards Pickering's Wharf, and her stern towards the river—I was broadside to her—I cannot say what colour the let
ters were painted in—I think they were gilted like gold letters.
MR. SLEIGH. Q. Were there other barges lying between the Old Soul and you? A. No.

WILLIAM HILLS . I am in the employ of the East and West India Docks. In May last, I was in the employ of Mr. Pickering—I went home ill on Sunday, 11th May—on the next Sunday, the 18th, between 9 and 10 o'clock in the morning, I was on the pier overlooking Pickering's Wharf—there was a barge being unloaded there—I noticed the name—it was the Old Soul, and contained guano—I went again in the afternoon, and saw them loading what I thought was guano into the Old Soul, but they were shorter bags than those
taken out in the morning, which I had noticed—I saw Long there—he was marking the bags—I was not with Legg—I was on the pier-head, nearest to Pickering's Wharf.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you go by any other name than Hill? A. No; I never went by the name of Heard—on 18th May I was lodging with Mr. Pickering's first mother-in-law, Mrs. Perkins—she then lived at 6, Brown's-buildings, Green-street, St. George's—I should say that is nearly four miles and a half from Pickering's Wharf—I never promised any marriage to Mrs. Perkins's daughter—she went and put the banns up unknown to me—I never knew it till it was done—I cannot say when it was done—I was not unwell on 18th May—I was not staying at my lodging all day—I do not know Richard Ellis, of Whiting-street, Waterloo-road, a shoe
maker—he was not to my knowledge in my company at Brown's-buildings, Green-street, St. George's, at 9 o'clock in the morning, of 18th May—I cannot say whether he was there, for I was gone—he was not with me all day—I was not unwell, and in bed at that time—there was no other man at my lodging with me—he did not remain with me till 5 in the afternoon—I never saw him to my knowledge.
(Richard Ellis was called, but did not appear.)

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Where were you standing? A. On the pier-head, forty yards I should say from the Old Soul—I can read and write—I am a labourer—I was not at work then—I had been out of work one week—I labour in the docks at present—the last man I worked for was Mr. Pickering—I was not turned away; I left on 11th May, on account of illness—Thomas, the policeman, found me out for a witness, and came to me—I mentioned to him what I had seen—I have never gone by any other name, and was never a witness before, nor summoned before a Magistrate.
COURT. Q. You were ill on 11th May? A. Yes, but not on the 18th—I continued ill two or three days—I kept at home all day Monday, 11th May, but not afterwards.

HENRY HORN . I am a labourer. On Saturday, 17th May, I was en
gaged near Pickering's Wharf—I saw two barges there, the Ann and tie Old Soul—I received directions from Joseph Dellmott to get men to work a barge—he used formerly to be a relation of Pickering's—in consequence of those directions, I went to work with some men at 3 o'clock on the Saturday, at the wharf, unloading the Ann and the Old Soul—we began to unload the Old Soul at 5, and went on till 9—the bags were taken to the first-floor of Mr. Pickering's premises—about 9 we had about half unloaded the barge—I saw Pickering there at 9, and we were paid, in his presence, 3s. each, for working from 3 o'clock—I received directions from Pickering to get ten men to come to work on Sunday morning, after breakfast—I got ten men next morning, and went to work—I saw Long there—we continued to unload the Old Soul—after she was unloaded, Pickering came—it was then past 10 in the morning—he said, "How are you getting on, lads?" and left directly—I did not go up-stairs—I was placed at the scale, to take the weights, and do what was required—stuff was put into the scale—it came from up-stairs—Long was at the scale while I was there—the bags which were brought from up-stairs were put into the scale, and were made weight according to the weight which Gibbs, the boy, gave from a book, with the number of the bag—the stuff was put in to make up that weight—the stuff came down in a basket from up-stairs—when that was done, I took the bag from the scale, and it was sewn up by two or three men, and put on board the Old Soul—one man
was named Pugb, and one Armagh—Mr. Long marled them—I only saw Pickering there once while I was weighing.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you see a barge there named Effort? A. No, there was no third barge there, to my knowledge—the Ann and the Old Soul were the only two I saw near to Pickering's Wharf—I am now a labourer, and have been abroad lately; I came back in March, 1850, from Gibraltar—I was sent there as a convict—I was there four years and seven months, going and coming back—it was a sentence of seven years, for felony; unlawful possession of carpenter's tools, for stealing them—I have been in custody once since I returned; that was last March; it was for in assault; throwing a man into the river—I have worked at the Docks lately, with any one who will employ me—Thomas, the policeman, applied to me to be a witness in this case—he found me at the Moor's Arms—I had not made any previous communication to him—he came to me first—to the best of my knowledge, it was five or six weeks ago.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Have, you been at work for the Messrs. Gibbs since this? A. No, for the Dock Company—I have only been in custody once since my return from transportation—I have been in custody for assault twice, but nothing else—the other time was for being drank and disorderly—I had been in custody before I was transported—I was imprisoned nine months for stealing lead—(I am twenty-seven years old)—before that I was in custody on suspicion of stealing some rope—I was innocent of that—I do not know what became of it—before that I was in custody for lead—I was sent to the House of Correction for six weeks—that was the first time I was in custody—I was never charged with stealing a silk-handkerchief and snuff-box from Ratcliff-highway; nothing of the kind—I am at work now—I was paid 13s. 2d. last night, by Mr. Knight, for five days and two hours' work—I have had no expenses here yet.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You were sentenced to be transported about five or six years ago? A. Yes; at that time I was tried on a previous conviction as well—I came away before my time, in consequence of my general good conduct, of which I have a certificate—since I have been in this country I have not been under any charge of dishonesty—I have been in charge for being drunk, and for throwing a man into the river—the man got out—I had a month's imprisonment or a fine of 5l., and I served the time—I do not think Pickering knew, when I went into his service, that I had been trans
ported—I have known him about fourteen months, and Long about seven months—the man was thrown into the river near the Britannia-bridge, Limehouse—I was working with Pickering at that time.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you remember telling Mr. Pickering you had been offered 5l. and a good situation if you became a witness in this case? A. I swear I did not—I saw Pickering at a public-house when Thomas, the officer, was there—I did not say, "This is Thomas, the officer; I am to have 5l. and a good situation"—Pickering did say, "You will be subpoenaed, go and speak the truth."

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was this in the presence of Thomas, the officer? A. No, nobody was present but him and me—it was on the Monday before he had his second remand—it was on the canal-bridge—I saw him very promiscuously; and he said there was a subpoena served on me, and I was to go and speak the truth—nothing passed about 5l., neither with Thomas nor did I tell Pickering so.
JAMES HOPSQN GIBBS . I am fifteen years old; I live with my parents in Thomas-street, Horselydown. In May last, I was in the service of Mr.

Pickering, as clerk—I know Mr. Long—on Saturday, 17th May, I was em
ployed at Union Wharf, Limehouse—I saw Mr. Long that afternoon—I can
not say at what time—it was before high-water—there were two barges at the wharf at that time—they were the Ann and the Old Soul—I had not seen the Effort—the Ann was loaded with hay—the Old Soul was moored to the tim
ber—she was laden with guano—when she was brought alongside the wharf, the guano was taken out—it was in bags—there was a number and weight on the bags—the number and weight of each bag was called out, and I put it down in a book belonging to Mr. Pickering, and I left it there—after the bags were landed from the Old Soul, some of them were taken to the ground-floor, and some up-stairs—I did not notice those on the ground-floor that evening—we went off work between 6 and 7 o'clock that evening—Mr. Pickering was then in the counting-house—I did not see him on the wharf while the Old Soul was unloading—when we left off work, I saw him come out of the counting-house to cross the wharf to go to his own house—he lives on the premises, and is the occupier of the whole wharf—he paid me that night—Mr. Long said it was Mr. Pickering's orders that we were to come to work the next morning—I reached the wharf the next morning about ten—I found the men at work—they were then putting it into the barge—I had not taken the weight and number of all of it on the night before—the men were at work in the morning when I got there—the barge had been unloaded, and while it was being reloaded I called the weights and numbers out which I had entered the night before; and when the men called out it was all right, I ticked them off—we worked that night till about five or six—I was not paid—I saw some foswill mixed with the guano, that had been taken from the Old Soul—the colour of the foswill is something like guano—when it was mixed with the guano it was put in the bags, and some of them were put in the Old Soul.
COURT. Q. Where was it mixed? A. Up-stairs—I was up there some part of the time—I was up and down—I saw Mr. Long up-stairs while it was being mixed—I do not know where Mr. Pickering was at the time.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You did not get there till 10 o'clock, or a little after, in the morning? A. No; I did not see Mr. Pickering that day—I was paid for that day's work on the next Saturday night—when I got there at ten in the morning, I found Henry Horn there—I recollect Mr. Pickering being taken into custody—I went to see him on the 2nd of August—I went in a cart with his brother-in-law, Mr. Dellmott, and Mrs. Pickering—Mrs. Pickering went, in first, and after that I went in—I was told he wanted to see me—I went in and he asked me if anybody had asked me any questions—I said "No"—no one had asked me any questions at that time—he said, "If anybody asks you anything, don't tell them," or "don't know," or words to that effect.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. What age are you? A. Fifteen—I had been in another employ—I knew the last witness, Horn, by sight—I know he has worked for Mr. Pickering—I have not been in the habit of going in his company no further than when he has been at work—I might have drank with him—he has never given me anything—I may have drank with him on the wharf—I was never in any public-house with him away from my master's—I never drank with him in any public-house—I know the White Hind in Thomas-street, in the Borough—I have been in there drinking—that is not the general way in which I pass my time, in drinking in public-houses—the way I came to be in the White Hind, was, I saw Mr. Long, and he said, "Go in and wait for me"—that was while he was out on bail—I went in and saw Horn there, and drank with him.
Q. What did you mean by telling me you had not drank with him? A. I

did not remember it—I remained with him there about half an hour—I had porter to drink, nothing else—I do not know what time it was—it was in the evening after we left work—we were in the parlour—we did not have any
thing to eat—we were sitting at a table talking—he did not tell me that he had been to Gibraltar—I mean to represent that when you asked me whether I had ever been with Horn in a public-house, that I had forgotten that I was half an hour with him at the White Hind—I do not remember being with him any other time—I will swear I had not drank with him in any public-house before that to my recollection—before I went to Mr. Pickering's I was in the employ of Mr. Hunt, a hop-factor—nothing happened to me at Mr. Hunt's—there was nothing wrong—it was said that I wrote a check—that I had forged it—I left Mr. Hunt's—I do not recollect exactly the amount of the check—I think it was for 10l.—it was on my master's bankers—it was said to be in my hand-writing—Mr. Hunt, my master, said that.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Your duty was to enter the weights in a book at Mr. Pickering's? A. Yes; this is the book in which I entered the weights—here is "Brig Effort" on it, in my writing—I recollect the Effort being there, and being unloaded and loaded again, but I cannot recollect the date—I cannot say whether it was on the same Saturday we have been speaking of, or whether it was not—when the weights are called out nothing is said about the name of the barge; they call the weight of the bags, and I write it down—Mr. Pickering would have to cross the wharf to go to his pri
vate residence—he could do that without seeing the barge or barges which were unloading—I went to the prison on one occasion with Mr. Dellmott—that was not in consequence of a communication I had with Mr. Hobler—my father had received a card from Mr. Hobler—that did not lead to my going to the prisoner.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did your father know you were going to the pri
son? A. No; I did not tell him I was going to the prison to see Pickering—I went with Mrs. Pickering—when I went to the public-house, Long was standing a little way down the street—he told me to go in and wait—he came in about five minutes afterwards—I had not done anything to the check—I was charged with forging—I was not given into custody—I went to Mr. Hunt, in the market, and explained it—the check was not my hand-writing—I never drew any check at all in my master's name, on his banker's—my master seemed to be satisfied, he nodded his head and said no more about it—I had left Mr. Hunt; this was while I was with Mr. Pickering—Mr. Pickering offered me his place, which was higher wages—Mr. Hunt's clerk told me I was charged with forging a check, and directly I heard that I went to see Mr. Hunt, and he never charged me with it, and seemed satisfied—I do not find in this book my entry of the things from the Old Soul—it was in this side of the hook—I left this book in Pickering's possession—here is the entry of the Effort—it is all in my writing—these are not the entries I made with reference to the Old Soul—the weights and numbers of the Old Soul were different—these are dated May 18th—the page before it is May 16th—there is no page with May 17th on it—these are not the weights and num
bers that I spoke of in my examination as entered from the Old Soul—I know I did not enter these from the Old Soul—it would be my duty to put the name of the vessel in the book—here is "Barge Effort"—this book is in the same state that it was when I made entries in it—supposing this to be the book in which I entered the goods from the Old Soul, I entered them at this end of the book, I was told so to do by Mr. Pickering—I know it was entered in a reverse way to the other entries—I believe it was in this part of the book where there seems to be some pages torn out.

COURT. Q. Can Pickering either read or write? A. He can figure a little, and write his own name—Long came into the White Hind five minutes after me—he remained there and drank with me and Horn—what we had was put down to Mr. Long.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was the entry of the guano that has been pointed out to you under the date 18th May what you made invoice of, and was it sent by Mr. Pickering to the railway on Mr. Messer's account? A. Yes; this figure (looking at it) is 8, it has been written over a 9—it was not done at the time the entry was made—I was told to write it by Mr. Pickering—I believe it is in the same ink as the 9, but it has been marked over twice—I believe this was done when Mr. Pickering was out on bail—(Delivery-order read—"London, 14th May. Please to weigh and deliver to Capt. Drury, or order, the under-mentioned goods, in the ship Invermore, 14 tons of guano. Anthony Gibbs and Son.")

WILLIAM HILLS
re-examined. Q. Do you see this man (Ellis); do you know him? A. No; I never saw him—I am sure I was not in his company on the 18th.

HENRY WOODFALL . I am a paper-manufacturer, and live at Foot's Cray, I have known Mr. Pickering four or five years—I always found him a very honest and straightforward man—I have done a good deal of business with him.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What do you know of him? A. I have bought rags of him—I do not know where he was last Whitsuntide—I never heard of his being given into custody for receiving stolen goods—I would do business with him again to-morrow.

GEORGE RUTLAND . I live in Jane-street, Commercial-road. I called at Mr. Pickering's Wharf on Sunday, 18th May—I got there from 9 to a quarter-past 9 o'clock, to the best of my recollection—I found some men at work at a material that I should imagine was guano—they were shipping it into the barge, the Effort, to the best of my recollection—I was eight or ten minutes looking at the men—I then went into Pickering's house—he was up; I staid and breakfasted with him, and he went out with me in his chaise-cart to Barking—I was with him the best part of the day—we came back between 7 and 8 in the evening—I parted with him in the Commercial-road.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I suppose you could not full to see the guano? A. No; no one could fail to see it if they went on the wharf—Mr. Pickering did not come out and see it—we came out of the passage-door—it was a custom I had of going out on a Sunday—it was agreed that we should go for a ride together—I noticed the barge Effort, it being rather a peculiar name—I do not know that I ever saw one with that name before—she was moored with the head towards the wharf, to the best of my recol
lection—there were other barges there—to the best of my recollection I never saw the Old Soul—I do not know whether the Ann was there—there was another barge with bags, and one with hay—the barge they were shipping the guano in was nearest to the wharf—I was on the wharf a few minutes—I heard of this when Mr. Pickering was apprehended—I saw him when he was on bail—he did not tell me the barge was the Effort—I did not ask him, I asked him nothing about it—I did not consider I had any busi
ness to do it—I might have been two or three times with him after this—I never had any direction from him—I have spoken to him about the matter, certainly—I have talked to him about it—he did not tell me he shipped it on board the Effort—he told me nothing at all about it—he told me nothing at all about shipping the guano—I cannot tell what he said—the name of the barge was never mentioned.

Q. you mean that you, seeing the name of the barge, and knowing he was charged with having shipped it to the Old Soul, the name was never mentioned? A. To the best of my knowledge it was not—I shall object to swear it was not, if I am in a right position by so doing—I will swear that he did not tell me it was the Effort—he did not tell me it was not the Old Soul—he did not tell me he had never seen the guano, to my knowledge; it never crossed us till he was apprehended—I do not know that I have asked him about it—he told me nothing about it—there was nothing further than common conversation—I do not know that ever he broached the subject, the technical parts of the subject—my curiosity was a little excited, but I never troubled my head about it—I remember, all the time back to May last, that this barge was the Effort—I told Pickering nothing about it—I was sent for by its coming across his wife's memory, I suppose—she saw me there—she did not tell me it was the Effort, nor did I tell her—I and Pickering never mentioned it—it is my solemn assertion that I never mentioned the name of the barge to him, or he to me, or his wife—my being there, on Sunday morn
ing fixes the name on my mind; and it was rather an unusual thing to see men at work—I never said to Pickering, "What an odd-named barge that was"—I mentioned she name to Mr. Sherwood—he asked me what I knew of this affair; and to the best of my recollection I gave him the same state
ment that I have to you—I knew the Effort had something to do with it by seeing it in the newspapers—I believe I saw the name Effort; I know I did—I saw the newspaper on Friday, and I saw Pickering on Saturday evening—I did not ask him anything about the matter.

EDWARD HOLMES . I live at Mile-end, and am a dealer in hay. I went to Pickering's Wharf on Sunday morning, 18th May, to look out six or seven loads of hay—I saw it in a barge—I went down to the barge to look at it—there were two barges there, which I went over, to get to the barge where the hay was—they were loaded with bags, which I supposed to be guano from the smell—the name of one of the barges was the Effort; the other I cannot say.

JOSEPH DELLMOTT . I am Mr. Pickering's carman. On 17th May, about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the barge Effort come into his wharf—she had guano on board—I cannot tell how many bags; I never kept count of them—I had been informed by Gibbs that there was an order for guano to he made up—on Monday, 19th, it was to go to the station—I was told I should have to work on Sunday; I grumbled at that—I got a gang of men on that Sunday—I was told to get them by Gibbs, and I ordered ten men—I applied to Horn to bring ten men over—the Effort was partly unloaded on Saturday evening—the gang came at 7 on Sunday morning—I did not see the master in the counting-house on Saturday or on Sunday—we finished unload
ing the Effort on the Sunday morning—we took the guano up in the loft to empty it out and put in other bags—we loaded the Effort again in the afternoon—the men left work at 6—the Effort left between 3 and 4 in the afternoon.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLAWTINE. Q. Was there any other vessel there on Saturday evening, or on Sunday morning, laden with guano? A. No; I will swear that.
COURT. Q. Was there any other vessel laden with bags? A. Yes; they did not smell like guano—the name of the other vessel with bags was the Ann—I am sure of that.
Q. Now I recommend you to think of what you are saying, and to be cautious: was there another barge loaded with hay? A. Yes; and that barge was not the Ann—I am certain of it.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you certain the Ann was loaded with bags? A. Yes, with bags of foswill; and it had no hay in it—I cannot tell what they do with foswill; it is put with the guano, I believe—I do not know whether Mr. Pickering does that—I believe it is his business.

WILLIAM CHAPMAN . I live in Thomas-street, Whitechapel, and am a general dealer. I went to Mr. Pickering's Wharf on 18th May, to buy some clover—there was a barge there; the name of it I think was the Ann—she had some trefoil—that is similar to hay—there was a barge or two there, but I did not notice them—I have seen the Old Soul—I did not notice her that day.

ARCHIBALD HORN . I was engaged by Henry Horn, to work at Pick
ering's Wharf, on 18th May—I worked from half-past 7 o'clock in the mom
ing till 7 at night, unloading guano from the barge called the Effort—I do not know whether the Old Soul barge was there.

JOSIAH HARRIS . I have known Mr. Pickering about twelve months; he has borne an honest character, as far as I know—there was something about some grease some time ago, and after that he brought an action against the party.

p.hi: declining to call other witnesses, Pickering called the following:

div1.p: JOSIAH HARRIS . I paid Pickering some money on 17th—I was on his wharf—I did not see the Old Soul barge there: I saw four or five; I got over two to look at some trefoil—I do not know the name of the barge the trefoil was in.

JOHN PARSONS . I was on the wharf—I could not say the day—it was when two barges of guano were there—they were partly loaded; I helped to unload the last in the evening, and again on the Sunday morning—I never noticed the name of the barges—Thomas offered me 5l.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Were you not examined before the Magistrate, and told the Magistrate that you noticed the Old Soul there? A. No; I did not notice the name—I did not say so—I could not do it, for I did not notice the name. LONG—
GUILTY of stealing.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. Aged 35.—
Confined Twelve Months.
PICKERING—
GUILTY of receiving. Aged 30.—
Transported for Ten Years. Dellmott and Parsons were committed for perjury.

1750.
THOMAS INSELL
, feloniously cutting and wounding
William Coggins, with intent to resist his lawful apprehension.—2nd COUNT, to main and disable him.—3rd COUNT, to do him some grievous bodily harm.
MR. BURNIE conducted the Prosecution,

WILLIAM COGGINS (policeman, M 336). On the morning of 19tb Aug., about a quarter to 1 o'clock, I was on duty in the Southwark-road, and heard a strange noise and quarrelling—I went and desired the prisoner and his woman who were there to go away quietly, and not make such a noise in the street—the woman said they would make as much noise as they liked—I said she must not, she must go along quietly, or I should take her to the station—the prisoner, who was ahead, came back and said, "I will soon give you something"—he ran away, and fetched an instrument, which looked in the dark like a poker, and struck me on the head with it; here is the mark—I fell on the ground, and he struck me several times while I was down—I prevented the blows as well as I could with my staff—the female only abused me—as he was coming along with the poker, she got before him and tried to prevent him—I kept hitting at his legs—I saw three or four people making towards me—he saw them and ran away—I got up imme
diately, and followed him—I was within a few yards of him when be entered

the door, which is about twenty yards off—he went in and shut the door; the woman went in also—I sprang my rattle—another constable came—we both sprang our rattles, to get more assistance—sergeant Golding came up, and I tapped at the door and shutter, and asked them to open it, but got no answer—a constable gave the door a push, and it opened; the latch seemed to fly back—he went in, and I followed—he caught the prisoner by the collar, and I by the left arm—I found his hand groping about my chest; it was dark—I could see nothing—he cut my coat through with a razor, made a strike at my hand, and cut my fingers—I called out to the others to look out, as he had got a knife, or something, and had cut my fingers—I immediately struck him on the head with my staff—I was bleeding profusely from my head and hand—I became faint from loss of blood, and left the house, and waited outside till the prisoner was brought out, when I was assisted to the station, and the surgeon dressed my bead and band.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Have you told us all that passed between you and the female and this man, before he went away, saying he would give you something? A. There were a great many very abusive words passed with her—she said she would make as much row as she liked—she was very drunk—I believe she staggered down—I think I gave her a slight push, just to move her on, because she stood calling me in such a way—I did not see her head go against the stones, nor did I hear it—she staggered, and fell down at a distance from me, after I gave her the slight push—her head did not come in contact with the stones that I know of—that occurred before the prisoner said he would give me something—he was not gone above a minute, or a minute and a half, before he came back again—he went round into Norfolk-street—he lives there, and is a barber by trade—when he came rushing at me with this poker, or whatever it was, I drew my staff—I cannot tell whether I touched him with it or not; I think I did, when I was on the pound, touch his legs once or twice, to keep him at a distance, so that he should not hit me—after he got up and went into the house, I followed him—there was only one man in the house before me, and sergeant Golding fol
lowed me in—only me and 285 had hold of the prisoner at the time he cut me; it was done nearly the moment we got hold of him—after he had used the razor I hit him on the head, which cut him back entirely—I believe this was one of the days of Camberwell fair; at least, this was on the Tuesday morning, about a quarter to I, and Camberwell fair was on the Monday—the prisoner did not appear the worse for liquor—the woman was not struck by any of us that I know of—I never struck her—I cannot say that she was or was not struck, as I left the house before the man was brought out.
MR. BURNIE. Q. You say you touched him when he was on the ground; was that before or after he struck you with the poker? A. After he had felled me to the ground.

THOMAS EASTICK (policeman, M 285). On Tuesday, 19th Aug., I was on duty in Southwark-bridge-road, and in consequence of information I received I went to Norfolk-street—I saw Coggins standing in the street, near a house, bleeding from the head—in consequence of what he told me I pushed the door open—it was fastened very lightly—I pushed against it with my band, and the door flew open—it was shut—I do not think there was any fastening—I did not see any damage done to the door when I pushed it open—I went into the front-room, which is a barber's shop, and saw the prisoner standing with an iron in his hand—I took him by the collar, and told him he must come with me to the station—Coggins followed close behind me, and took him by the collar on the other side—the prisoner resisted at first, until

we got him out of doors, then he did not—I believe he struck Coggins with a razor—Coggins said he had cut his finger off—I cannot say whether Cog
gins then struck the prisoner; I did not see him; there was a light—I turned my lamp on when I went in—he did not strike him when my lamp was on—when he cried out, my lamp was out—I did not hear Coggins strike any blow—I struck at him, but I cannot say whether I hit him in the head or not—some other constables came up, and among us we took the prisoner to the station—a surgeon was sent for, who dressed Coggins's wounds.

Cross-examined. Q. You were examined before the Magistrate; was not this the way in which the thing happened: did Coggins go to take hold of the prisoner? A. Yes; that was after I had seized the prisoner by the collar, and told him he must come with me—when Coggins went to take hold of him the prisoner made a back-handed blow at him, and then Coggins said, "He has cut me!"—I cannot say whether Coggins then gave the prisoner a blow on the head which made it bleed.

COURT. Q. What do you mean by you cannot say? A. I cannot say whether he struck him or not—I had got hold of his collar when I laid on the ground—I did not see him strike him—I cannot say whether he struck him or not.

MR. PAYNE. Q. On your oath did not Coggins give the prisoner a blow on the head which made his head bleed? A. I cannot say whether be did—I was looking at the prisoner—I saw that his head was bleeding when I went out—I did not see or hear a blow given—I do not think I gave him a blow that made his head bleed—I struck at him—I cannot say whether I struck him or not—I cannot say whether his head was bleeding from a blow from me or Coggins—I never saw Coggins strike him.

JOSHUA'GOLDING (police-sergeant, M 7). On Tuesday morning, 19th Aug., I went to Norfolk-street, a little after 1 o'clock in the morning—I saw the two constables standing close to the door—Coggins was bleeding profusely from a wound in the head—in consequence of what he said, I went into the house—the door was forced open by Eastick—I followed Coggins in—the first thing I saw was the prisoner's hand, with a razor in it, flourishing it—he was in a stooping position, under the two constables, when I first turned my light on—I immediately took my truncheon, and struck his hand, and he dropped the razor; I then got hold of his hand, and held him—the light was then turned off—there was a blow or two struck, but who struck it I cannot say—there was no light—I did not see the prisoner's head bleeding till I got out of the house—I did not see Coggins's hand bleeding then—he complained of it being cut—he had a handkerchief round it—I left the prisoner with two constables, and assisted Coggins to the station.

EDWARD COLEMAN (policeman, M 53). I went to the prisoner's house on the morning of 19th Aug., and took this poker from the fireplace—a part of it was covered with hair and blood, and something white, and the handle was smeared all over with it—all where it is now rusty was then blood.

GEORGE ODLING . I am a surgeon. I was sent for to the station, to dress Coggins's wounds—he appeared a good deal exhausted from the exertion, and from the wounds—he was bleeding from the head, and a good deal from the finger—the wound in the head was about an inch and a half long—I did not consider it dangerous—it was a severe contusion—I did not probe it—it was a very likely wound to have been produced by the corner of this poker—the wound on the hand was incised, and inflicted by a sharp instru
ment, such as a razor—it was cut to the bone, and divided three parts of the circumference—I expect he will get the use of the finger in a month or two.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there much bleeding from the finger? A. There bad been—there were two fingers cut, one very slightly—I sponged and washed it. and brought the edges together, but did not probe it—it was not at all a dangerous wound. (The prisoner received a good character.)

p.rs: GUILTY on 3rd Count, Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury.

div1.p:
Aged 33.—
Confined Four Months.

1751.
JAMES DYSON
, robbery on
William Beswick, and stealing 1 watch, value 3l.; his property.

WILLIAM BESWICK . I am a clerk, and live at 17, Victoria-place, Peter-street, Was worth. On the night of 10th June, about half-past 12 o'clock, I was at the Rodney, in Westminster-bridge-road, standing close to the bar—I saw the prisoner standing close to me—I had a silver watch fastened to a gold guard—as I was in the act of leaving the bar, I felt a tug at my pocket so violent, that it actually pulled my neck down; and with the tug I felt and beard a wrench—I looked down, and saw the prisoner's hand coming from my pocket with the guard hanging in his hand—I seized hold of his hand, and likewise of his collar, and called out that I was robbed—I said to him, "I am robbed, and you are the man that has done it!"—I did not see the watch—a policeman rushed in instantly—I picked up my watch close to the prisoner's feet—I did not see who dropped it.

Cross-examined by MR. COCKLE. Q. There were a great number of persons there, were there not? A. Not a great many—it is a small bar—I was not there six minutes altogether—there was a woman there—I saw no policeman there when I went in—I will swear that I taw the prisoner's hand at my pocket when I felt the jerk, and the guard in his hand minus the watch—I was perfectly sober.

SAMUEL LEWIS (policeman, P 260). I went into the Rodney about half-past 12 on the night of the 10th—the prisoner was given into the custody of a brother constable—I asked him where the watch was—he said he had not had it—I told my brother constable to search him; as soon as he heard that, he tried to get away—I stood with my back to the door—his right-hand was in his right-hand trowsers-pocket—he drew it from his pocket, and something dropped on the floor—we looked, and there was the watch—the prosecutor picked it up, and I took the prisoner out of the house—as we were going along, he called out to a mob who were following to assist him—he said, "Come on, I will be off!"—he got away—I did not lose sight of him.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not see the watch till you saw it on the floor? A. No; I know that he dropped something—there were from nine to a dozen persons there—there was a woman standing against the bar, two or three feet from where the watch fell—Etheridge went in before me—he had hold of the prisoner at the time I saw his hand in his pocket.

JOHN ETHERIDGE (policeman, L 35). I went into the public-house, and saw Mr. Beswick holding the prisoner—he gave him into my custody for stealing a silver watch—the prisoner said he did not steal it—Mr. Beswick had a chain hanging round his neck—I took the prisoner from his hands—soon afterwards Mr. Beswick said, "Here is my watch"—I picked it up at the prisoner's feet—I took him out of the house, and he escaped, but I got him again—he struggled violently to get away, and kept hallooing to some pals, who were behind.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear anything fall? A. No; I had hold
of him when Mr. Beswick picked up the watch—this is the watch (produced)—I did not see it picked up—I was busy with the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1752.
GEORGE EDMUND STOLWORTHY
, feloniously forging and uttering a receipt for 2l. 2s.; with intent to defraud
James Browell: alto
ob
taining 1 sovereign, and 1 shilling; the moneys of
Henry Marshall Hughes, by false pretences: to both which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 67.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1753.
WILLIAM GOOCH
, stealing 1 gun, 1 gun-case, and 3 printed books, value 8l.; the goods of
William Clapperton, his master.

WILLIAM CLAPPERTON . I keep the Kenilworth Castle, public-house, New North-road, Islington. The prisoner was my potboy, and had been so three or four months—I had a gun in a case in the club-room—I saw it there on 15th July, between 10 and 11 o'clock, and missed it about half-past 10 in the evening—I was told something, and went to M'Carthy, and, in conse
quence of something he told me, I went to Bermondsey-street, where I saw the prisoner coming out of a public-house with my gun in his hand—he was very tipsy—I gave him in charge—I also lost three books the same evening.

WILLIAM M'CARTHY . I live in Shepperton-street, Islington. On 18th July, a little after 10 o'clock in the evening, I was at Mr. Clapperton's—the prisoner asked me to carry a gun out for him—he was in the yard, just out
side the door, and said he was going home that evening, over the water—he had got the gun in his hand—I asked if it was his own—he said, "Yes"—he was a little in liquor—I carried the gun about twenty yards outside the door—it was in two pieces, and not in the case—he came out with a little can, and some beer, and brought two or three little books which be asked me to take care of for him till the morning—I agreed to do so—he took the gun and went away—next morning I gave the books to Mr. Clapperton.

DANIEL MILLS (policeman, M 173). On 20th July, I was on duty, and saw the prisoner coming out of the Anchor and Eight Bells, Bermondsey-street, with this gun—it was put together, and the case was swinging on his arm—Mr. Clapperton came up in a cab, and gave him in custody—he was very tipsy—I received these books from M'Carthy next morning.

WILLIAM CLAPPERTON
re-examined. This is my gun, and books—I never lent him the gun—it had a lock on it, which is gone now.

Prisoner. I was in the habit of bringing books home, and have got some now; I lent your sister some books, and she lent me some in return, Witness. I was not aware of it—my sister lives in the house—she is unmarried—he never went out shooting, or talked about it.

Prisoner's Defence. I took the gun with the intention of going out for a day's shooting, and returning on Thursday morning; I asked M'Carthy to take the gun out that it might not be noticed; I intended to take the books back, but being very tipsy was afraid I should lose them.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

1754.
HENRY PEARCE
, embezzling 16s.; the moneys of
George Philip Davis, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Seven Days.

1755.
WILLIAM DUFFEY
, stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; 2 half-crowns. 1 sixpence, 1 penny, and 1 halfpenny; the property of
Edward Edwards, from the person of
Isabella Edwards: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Seven days, and
Whipped.

1756.
CHARLES JOHN COOPER and
WILLIAM CROMER
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; the goods of
Parkins Jones, from his persons. 2nd COUNT, charging Cromer with receiving.

PARKINS JONES . I am relieving-officer of Fulham Union. On 3rd July, between 7 and 8 o'clock, I was at Putney fair—a policeman spoke to me, and I missed my handkerchief, which I had seen two minutes before—I saw the prisoners run away, jump over a ditch, and run into the osiers—I saw a handkerchief pass between them—the policeman pursued, and took them.

LIONEL HODDER (policeman, V 52). I produce a certificate of the death of the policeman, Edward Cock—I saw him dead—I was present when he was examined before the Magistrate—his deposition was read over to him, and the prisoners had an opportunity of cross-examining him—(Edward Cock's deposition was here read as follows: "I am a constable, No. 245 V; on the evening of 3rd July I saw the prisoners together in Finch's-field, Putney, where a fair was held; seeing them attempt to pick several pockets, I watched them two hours, and then saw them behind Mr. Jones; I spoke to Mr. Jones, and with him followed the prisoners; they ran away into the osier-beds, among the mud and dirt, and tried to make their escape; I followed, and saw the handkerchief close to Cromer's feet, in the osiers.")—I was with Cock that day watching the prisoners—I saw each of them make several attempts at gentlemen's pockets—they both closed behind Mr. Jones Cooper appeared to be tugging at his pocket—he appeared to pass some
thing to Cromer—they then moved away in a great hurry, and I spoke to thing Mr. Jones—we followed the prisoners into the osier-bed—just as I got by the tide of Cromer, he threw this handkerchief (produced) in between the osiers—I took Cooper, and my brother constable took Cromer and the hand
kerchief.

PARKINS JONES
re-examined. This is my handkerchief.

COOPER—
GUILTY of Stealing. Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

CROMER—
GUILTY of Receiving. Aged 18.—He was also charged with

p.hi:
having been before convicted; to which he pleaded Guilty.—
Transported for Seven Years.

div1.p:
1757.
PETER DAVIS
, stealing 2 tame rabbits, 1 basket, and 2 knifes, value 5s. 4d.; the goods of
Thomas Craft.

SIMEON WAGHORN (policeman, L 101). On 8th Aug., about 3 o'clock in the morning, I was on duty in Jonathan-street, Vauxhall, and saw the prisoner, about forty yards from the prosecutor's, standing, with a basket in one hand, and a rabbit in the other—he was stroking it—I was in my uniform—he could see me—I went up to him, put my hand into his basket, and said, "What have you got here?"—he said, "Another rabbit"—! said, "What are you going to do with them?"—he said the one he was stroking was a buck, and the other he was going to take to the buck, to 17, Vauxhall-street—it was dark—I asked where he lived—he said, "Two or three doors below a rag
shop in Jonathan-street"—I asked him his name—he said, "Brown," and that he was waiting for his brother—I said I very much doubted what he said, and he threw the rabbits down, and ran away—I pursued him, and he was stopped by another constable—I never lost sight of him—I afterwards saw the basket at the station, and found two knives in it—I found some matches and several pieces of candle in his pocket.
JAMES PIPER (policeman, L 76). I stopped the rabbits, picked up the basket, and gave it to Waghorn—I did not examine the contents—I put no knives into it.

ANN CRAFT . I am the wife of Thomas Craft; he keeps tame rabbits in our yard, in Jonathan-street; it is fenced in. The policeman showed me two rabbits, a basket, and two knives, which were mine—I had seen them safe at 10 o'clock the night before, and missed them next morning.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the things of a man and boy, for 4s.

GUILTY . ** Aged 17.—He was also charged with having been before convicted; to which he pleaded Guilty.—
Confined Six Months.

1758.
EDWARD JONES
, stealing 1 towel, 90 envelopes, and 3 pencils, value 1s. 9d.; the goods of the
London, Brighton, and South-coast Rail
way Company, his employers.

JOHN CARPENTER (police-sergeant, R 38.) On 11th July, I took the prisoner into custody in the Old Kent-road, and told him he was charged with taking a towel from a parcel going to Brighton—he said, "I must acknowledge that I have taken that; I am very sorry for it"—I asked him where it was—he said at home, and he would go and fetch it—I went with him to his house, found the towel, and also some envelopes and pencils with the Com
pany's mark on them.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not say I had taken the towel home to get it washed, and it was in the wash-tub? A. You did not say it was in the wash-tub, but I found it there—you asked your wife for it, and she took it out of the tub.

HENRY BERRY . I am a receiving-porter of the London, Brighton, and South-coast Railway. On 7th July, I received a parcel from Mrs. Hawkins, directed to Mr. Hawkins, and which was to be delivered at Brighton—there were several packages; one was in a very loose condition—the prisoner weighed them, and I left them in his charge—one parcel consisted of bedding.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not tie them up tighter? A. I ordered the carman to tie one up tighter before I would receive it—they were all loose—I did not see any of the contents drop out.

CHARLOTTE ANN HAWKINS . My husband is a carpenter; we lived in London. In July we were removing to Brighton, and sent eleven packages by Pickford's to the Bricklayer's Arms Station—this towel, which is my hus
band's, was in one of the parcels of bedding, which was tied up in a counter
pane—the towel did not reach Brighton.
Prisoner. Q. If I had picked the mark out, could you have sworn to it? A. No.

WILLIAM ACTON . I am chief superintendent of police on the London, Brighton, and South-coast Railway. The prisoner was employed as a porter; these seventy envelopes are such as the Company use, and have the Com
pany's name on the seal—the pencils are similar to what the Company use, and have the same maker's name on them—the porters have no business with them—the envelopes are kept in drawers in the office.
Prisoner's Defence. Last year I was receiving-porter, and could have whatever I liked to ask for, and I have had these envelopes and Pencils ever since.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 29.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined One Month .

1759.
JAMES PEARLE
, stealing two gowns, value 2l.; the goods of
Betsy Danes.

JAMES LINE (policeman, N 282.) In consequence of information, and receiving this duplicate (produced) from a man named Cole, I went to Mr. Cockburn, pawnbroker, at Richmond—I produced the duplicate, and was shown a gown—I received a description of the person who had pledged it; and in consequence found the prisoner—I asked him if he had lost a duplicate; he said "No"—I showed him this ticket, and said, "Do you know anything about this?"—he said, "No"—I asked him to go to a public-house with me, and he refused—I asked him where he was the day this property was pledged; he said he should not tell me—as we were going to the station, I saw his hand in his pocket—I had a struggle with him, and in his hand I found a duplicate for two blankets, and at the station I found another duplicate.

JOSEPH GRIFFIN . I am assistant to Mr. Cockburn, pawnbroker, of Rich
mond. I produce a silk gown, pledged on 7th July by the prisoner—I gave him the duplicate produced.
BETSY DAVIES . I am a widow. This gown is mine, and has my work on it—I saw it safe within a few days of missing it—the prisoner lodged at my home.

GUILTY Aged 40.—
Confined, Three Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1760.
CHARLES SIMMONS
stealing 1 barrow, value 50s.; the goods of
Henry Conman; also,
1 truck, value 4l.; the goods of
John Edward Smith: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . * Aged 20.—
Confined Nine Months.

1760.
JOHN PRIOR
, embezzling on 10th May, 3l. 10s.; the moneys of
William Shaw, his master.
MR. ROBINSON conducted the Prosecution,

WILLIAM HOOD . I am in the service of Mr. Shaw, a hay-salesman; the prisoner was also in his service. On 10th May, I sent him out with a load of hay to sell—he returned between 7 and 8 o'clock—I asked him whether be had sold it, he said he had—I asked whether he had the money—he said no, he should have it in a fortnight—on 21st June, I was at Smithfield-market, and had three loads of clover there, which I sold to a person we call Joe, for 4l. 6s.;—I told the prisoner to go with him, and Joe said, as soon as the clover was unloaded there would be ready tin—I said, "Do you mean money?"—he said, "Yes"—I sent the prisoner with the load, and in the evening I met the prisoner and Joe in the Old Kent-road, and asked him if he had got the money—he said he had got 3l., that the old woman had got no more, and the old man was not at home—he gave me the 3l.—he did not state the person's name to whom the clover was sold—he remained in the service a couple of weeks, and then left of his own accord—three or four days after he was taken into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. You then saw him in Smithfield? A. Yes; Mr. Shaw is in the habit of attending there, and selling hay—Long Joe was not present when the prisoner told me he had only got 8l.—I had told Long Joe not to be in that cart, but be off about his business—the prisoner only sold hay on credit, when I or Mr. Shaw gave him orders so to do—I do not know if Joe is here.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Joe took the clover away, and the prisoner went with him? A. Yes; the prisoner went, to bring back the money—if he received
the 4l. 6s., it was his daty to bring it back to me—he brought me the 3l., and told me that was all he had received.

The evidence given in this case having reference to another indictment, MR. GORNEY suggested that that indictment might be proceeded with, no father evidence being adduced on the present. MR. ROBINSON proposed to withdraw the present indictment. MR. GURNEY was, however, of opinion that there should be a verdict of
NOT GUILTY; the Jury could not be discharged without the consent of both parties; and, Mr. PARRY not consenting, the Jury found the prisoner
NOT GUILTY .

1762.
JOHN PRIOR was again indicted
for embezzling, on 26th June. 2l. 12s. 6d.; the moneys of
William Shaw, his master.

WILLIAM HOOD . On 26th June, I directed the prisoner to take half a load of bay, which came to 1l. 17s. 6d., and half a load of straw, 15s., to Mr. Parson's, at Fish-street-hill—he was to receive the money and bring it back—he did not bring the money to me—I saw him when he returned, but had not time to speak to him.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. You were very busy? A. He went away before I came back out of the office—I asked him next morning for it—he remained in our service two days after that, and was taken into custody at Smithfield, where I attend.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. What did he say the next morning? A. He told me he had lost it.
WILLIAM SHAW . The prisoner has not paid me the 2l. 12s. 6d.

JOHN PARSON . I lived with John Connett, my son-in-law, a butcher of Fish-street-hill. I purchased some hay and straw in Smithfield; it was delivered at Dowgate-hill—the prisoner then came back to Fish-street-hill, and I saw him paid the money, 2l. 12s. 6d.
NOT GUILTY .

1763.
JOHN PRIOR was again indicted
for embezzling, on 21st June, 1l. 6s.; the moneys of
William Shaw, his master.

p.hi: This was the indictment to which the evidence given in the first case applied.

div1.p:
MR. PARRY applied to withdraw the plea of
NOT GUILTY, and put in a plea of AUTREFOIS ACQUIT, which he submitted he was entitled to do at any period within six days. MR. GURNEY, after having consulted MR. JUSTICE WIGHT
MAN, was of opinion that he could not receive the plea.

WILLIAM HOOD . On 21st June I sold Joe a load of clover, and sent the prisoner with him to receive the money—it was his duty when he had received it to pay it over to me—4l. 6s. was the amount—I next saw him in the Old Kent-road, when he paid me 3l. for the clover, and said that was all the money he had got, the old woman had not got any more, and the old man was not at home, and he would pay it in a fortnight, when he went that way.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. How long after that did be remain in Mr. Shaw's service? A. Till 28th—it was Long Joe who bought the hay—I do not know where he is—Mr. Ostler is not Long Joe—I did not sell it to Ostler—I have dealt with Mr. Ostler before, but not with Joe.
COURT. Q. The prisoner had no authority to sell it to Mr. Ostler? A. No.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. But he was to get the money and bring it back to you? A. Yes.
MR. PARRY. Q. From Joe? A. He was either to bring back the money or the hay.

Mr. ROBINSON. Q. He was not to allow the hay to go out of his pesses
sion unless he got the money? A. No; nothing was said about getting it from anybody else—the prisoner was not in the habit of selling hay for me, without I gave him directions—I did so occasionally, but not on this occasion Joe was not with the prisoner at first, but came afterwards—they would not tell me where they were going to take the hay.

WILLIAM OSTLER . I am a carman, at 16, Earl-street, Finsbury. On 21st June I bought a load of hay—Joe and the prisoner brought it together—I put the prisoner 4l. 7s.—he gave me this receipt, and put his cross to it (produced: This was a bill headed, "Mr. Ostler, bought of Mr. Shaw," amounting to 4l. 7s.; settled, John Prior's mark)—I do not suppose I should hive bought it only I saw Mr. Shaw's name on the cart.

p.hi: being of opinion upon this evidence that the money in question was not received by the prisoner in virtue of his employment, the Jury found

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

1764.
JAMES RICHARDSON
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Young; with intent to steal.
MR. CAARTEEN conducted the Prosecution,

FREDERICK CHAPPLE . I am waiter at the White Hart public-house, Park-street, Southwark, which is kept by Mr. Young, it is in St. Saviour's parish. On Wednesday evening, 13th Aug., between 8 and 9 o'clock, the prisoner came and went into the bagatelle-room, which is up-stairs, and adjoins my master's bed-room—a panel of the bed-room door has been broken, and is mended with a piece of sacking, nailed over it inside, and then there is a piece of wood nailed across the sacking to keep it firm—about half-past 9, I missed the prisoner from the bagatelle-room, where I had seen him ten minutes before—I went down-stairs, spoke to Mrs. Young, and in conse
quence of what she said I went up-stairs again, and while going up saw the prisoner coming through the panel of the door—he came down-stairs, passed me on the stairs, and I followed him to the door—Mrs. Young had followed me op-stairs, and went into the bed-room—at the front-door the prisoner looked round', saw me, and ran away—I followed, and caught him about twenty yards from the house—he up with his fist and ran. down Fishmonger-alley—I cried, "Stop thief!" and he was stopped in the alley by Richards—when he was stopped I saw him stoop down by the side of the wall, and heard something jingle—a light was afterwards brought, and the policeman picked up two skeleton keys on the spot in my presence.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. How many persons were in the bagatelle-room? A. About six—the bed-room door is at the side of the bagatelle-room door—half the panel was out—a man must kneel down to get through—I do not know in what condition the door was that evening—I know it was half-past 9 o'clock when I missed him, because there is a clock in the bar and I went down to inquire whether he had passed the bar.

ELIZA YOUNG . I am the wife of John Young, who keeps the White Hart. On 23rd Aug. Chappie came to me about twenty minutes or half-past 9 o'clock; I followed him up-stairs, and as we were going up I saw the prisoner, but did not see where he came from—I said, "Watch him! watch him!"—he was then on the same stair as me—he darted off out of the house as quick as possible, and Chappie followed him—I went up-stairs and found the aperture in my door had been opened, the wood was entirely removed, and the sacking from one side, and left on the nails on the other—the door was still locked—I had
seen it about 9, or a few minutes before, and it was quite safe then—I searched the room, but missed nothing.

JOHN ROBERT MORRIS . I am a ginger-beer manufacturer, at 13, Fish
monger-alley. On 13th Aug., about a quarter to 10 o'clock, I was at my door talking to a neighbour, and heard a cry of "Stop thief!"—I got into a corner by Mr. Watson's premises—the prisoner ran up to me, I said, "Halloo!" and he chucked something over the wall into Mr. Watson's yard—I afterwards went and spoke to Mr. Watson.
WILLIAM WATSON . I am a hat-manufacturer, at 76, Redcross-street. Mr. Morris spoke to me—I went into my yard, which adjoins Fishmonger, alley, and there found this case of picklocks (produced).

THOMAS RICHARDS (policeman, M 10). I was in Fishmonger-alley on 13th Aug., about 10 minutes to 10 o'clock, heard a cry of "Stop thief!" and saw the prisoner running towards me—I laid hold of him, and he said, "Let me go, you b——r"—he took his hand from his pocket, and stooped down, and I heard something jink—I called for a light, and at his feet found there two skeleton-keys (produced)—Chappie came up, and I took the prisoner to the station—I afterwards went to the prosecutor's, and found these keys would unlock all the drawers.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Twelve Months ,
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 15TH.
